Dear Jennifer Lynn Trotter:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
FOR CWL ONLY
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area Manager at 734-395-0920
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12404
Section (1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who is legally
Description related to the child, is a legal custodian, or in a licensed foster
home, except as permitted in R 400.12709.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation • Youth A (age 16) went AWOL from her foster home on the
evening of 1/12/2023; and she returned to the foster home
earlier the next morning.
• On 1/13/2023 Youth A attended school and was in the
presence of her counselor due to concerns Youth A would
AWOL again.
• Foster Care Worker (FCW) 3 agreed to pick Youth A from
school on 1/13/2023. The FCW 3 did so but did not return
Youth A immediately. FCW 3 completed a safety plan with
Youth A around AWOLing. The plan included having Youth
A to go to a friend’s home if Youth A felt like running away.
• The foster parent strongly objected to the plan due to
concerns they had with the friend’s mother.
• On 1/14/2023 Youth A went to the friend’s home, after she
ran again. The agency told the foster parents Youth A
would stay with the friend’s family for four plus days, until
they were able to locate a placement for Youth A.
• The agency completed a safety plan for a youth which
consisted of placing the youth in an unlicensed, unrelated
home for four plus days.
2

Investigation Interviews:
Complainant/Foster Parent.
On 1/8/2023 I attempted to contact the complainant by telephone;
and on 1/19/2023, I spoke with Youth A’s foster father, Foster
Parent B by telephone.
Foster Parent B confirmed the information indicated in the
complaint and provided further details. He reported the agency
had been helpful to him and his wife Foster Parent C, so he
debated about complaining. He reported on 1/13/2023 instead of
Youth A taking the bus to school, as she normally did, he drove
her; and arranged for Youth A to speak to/stay with her counselor
because they were concerned about Youth A having “free rein”
and running away. He and his wife also took Youth A’s cell phone
due to those concerns, and arranged for FCW 3 to pick Youth A
up from school because Youth A did not want him, or Foster
Parent C to pick her up.
Foster Parent B reported when FCW 3 picked Youth A up, FCW 3
worked out a safety plan with Youth A, around what Youth A could
do if she felt like running away, without their input. The plan was
that Youth A could go to Friend D’s home, who would call the
agency. Friend D is a young lady whom Youth A met while placed
in the foster home of Foster Parents B and C. Friend D lived with
her family in the same neighborhood as Foster Parent B and C.
Foster Parent B said he and Foster Parent C were not okay with
the safety plan, but they understood the agency’s need to put
something in place. Foster Parent B expressed they were
concerned because they viewed Friend D’s mother as being too
lenient Additionally, he expressed that Friend D had her own
“issues.”
Foster Parent B reported on Saturday (1/14/2023) Youth A was
gone when he and Foster Parent C awakened. He and Foster
Parent C discovered Youth A had gone to a store. Youth A had
called Parent E who picked her up and called the agency. The
agency then called Foster Parents B and C to make them aware
of the situation. Youth A reported she did not want to return to the
foster home. Foster Parent B reported Youth A had been
consistently expressing that she did not want to return to the foster
home.
Foster Parent B reported the agency told him they were going to
allow Youth A to remain in Parent E’s home until another
placement could be found. He said, when the agency realized
3

they could not get another placement timely; the agency reported
they would just let Youth A stay at Parent E’s (identified by the
agency as a Kinship person), but Youth A’s legal placement would
remain with him and Foster Parent C. Foster Parent B said, he
and Foster Parent C disagreed with that proposed plan out of
possible liability concerns, and around disturbing items they had
seen on Youth A’s phone related to contacts with Friend D about
Youth A sneaking out to meet men. Foster Parent B said he and
Foster Parent C put in a 30-day removal request on 1/13/2023.
He and Foster Parent C rescinded that request and completed
paperwork for Youth A’s immediate removal on 1/14/2023 or
1/15/2023. Foster Parent B said the agency kept Youth A in
Parent E’s home. Youth A was still at Parent E’s home as of
1/19/2023. The agency was looking for a residential placement for
Youth A.
Agency Staff Interviews
On 2/3/2023 I interviewed Program Manager 2, and FCW 3 onsite.
They both indicated Youth A knew Friend D and Friend D’s family
for a while prior to the agency allowing Youth A to live with the
family. Youth A met Friend D and Parent E a year ago, via Youth
A’s school. Parent E worked at the school, and she had Youth A
over to their home several times prior to Youth A’s placement
there. Youth A was having friendship visits with Friend D and the
family while Youth A was in placement with Foster Parent B and
Foster Parent C. Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C allowed,
and were okay with, those interactions until an incident in October
2022.
Program Manager (PM) 2 reported FCW 3, is the agency’s
licensing manager whose has been serving in a dual role. FCW 3
was working with Youth A and Foster Parent B and Foster Parent
C. PM 2 reported on 1/14/2023 she gave the verbal approval for
Youth A to stay with Parent E’s family. The agency completed a
written Relative Placement Safety Screen (MDHHS-5770)
assessment on 1/24/2023.
FCW 3 (Licensing Manager) affirmed that Youth A AWOLed on
1/12/2023. Youth A reportedly ran to a male friend of her father’s.
Youth A was returned to the foster home by the police. FCW 3
said Youth A has a history AWOLing as well as, vaping, and
marijuana use, but Youth A did not begin AWOLing from this
placement until after a 10/31/2022 incident. On 10/31/2022,
Foster Parent B picked Youth A up from Friend D’s Home, earlier
than planned, after discovering Youth A had not completed her
homework. At that time Youth A refused to go back to Foster
4

Parent B’s and Foster Parent C’s home. Youth A was upset about
being picked up early, that the foster parents had taken her
phone, and about other foster home family rules. Youth A refused
to get in Foster Parent C’s car and FCW 3 was contacted. FCW 3
encouraged Youth A to get in the car. At that time, Foster Parent
C reported smelling marijuana on Youth A and Youth A gave an
excuse that it was due to Friend D’s whole house smelling of
marijuana. FCW 3 said she helped Youth A, and Foster Parent B
and Foster Parent C work things out. She convinced the foster
parents to give Youth A’s phone back and they all addressed
Youth A completing her homework. FCW 3 reported throughout
Youth A’s placement, with Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C,
they reported concerns with Youth A not being truthful and not
completing her homework, which was not unusual for Youth A.
FCW 3 said after Youth A ran on 1/12/2023, she was to complete
a well-child check on 1/13/2023. Her plan was to go to the foster
home, but after Foster Parent B advised her of Youth A’s refusal
to come home with him from the school, she went to Youth A’s
school. She denied that she did not apprise Foster Parent B and
Foster Parent C of what was going on with Youth A after she
picked Youth A up from school on 1/13/2023. She said she
picked Youth A up from school around 2:30PM. Youth A was
anxious and very upset over her phone being taken, Foster Parent
B and Foster Parent C being controlling, and issues with her
father. Youth A’s distress and anxiety was very visible, and to the
point that verbal intervention via New Oakland Crisis Center was
sought to calm Youth A. FCW 3 said afterwards she took Youth A
to McDonald’s to talk. She contacted Foster Parent B and Foster
Parent C by telephone and texted to let them know what was
going on. She returned Youth A to the foster home around
6:00PM and stayed for a while to get Youth A more stabilized.
They completed a safety plan during that time to identify things
Youth A could do around AWOLing. FCW 3 reported the safety
plan included:
• Youth A calling the help network, and or FCW 3.
• Youth A asking a to use the foster parent’s phone to make
the calls.
• Youth A having time in her room or watching T. V. to de-
stress.
• Youth A having time alone, not being required to talk with
Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C unless it’s her choice.
• No cell phone media use, unless under one of the foster
parent’s supervision with the foster parent’s phone.
• If Youth A was to run away, she will go Friend D’s home.
5

FCW 3 said the foster parents agreed to the safety plan but did
not like it because they questioned whether it would avert Youth A
from AWOLing. Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C also did not
like that Youth A would not talk with them about what she was
going through. Nor that Youth A could use Youth A’s cell phone.
They were opposed to the latter because they had seen
inappropriate pictures of a sexual nature, Youth A naked in a
video on the phone, and an explicit text message between Youth
A and a male person. Additionally, a text from Friend D to Youth A
asking Youth A not to tell Parent E that Friend D was with a
certain person. FCW 3 reported those things and a belief that
Parent D would allow Youth A to use Friend D’s phone to reach
out to inappropriate men fueled Foster Parent B’s and Foster
Parent C’s concern that Parent E’s home was not an appropriate
placement for Youth A. Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C
were concerned Parent E could not provide Youth A the level of
care and supervision they would/that Youth A needed.
FCW 3 reported Youth A living with Parent E was not planned and
the family is not blood related to Youth A. Youth A identified the
family as a safe place to stay in a safety plan that was developed
around Youth A AWOLing. FCW 3 reported when Youth A ran the
morning of 1/14/2023 and refused to return to the foster home, the
agency reached out to the licensed foster homes they have, that
typically take teens. The agency did not have a foster parent
willing to take placement of Youth A. At that point, the agency
believed it was okay to leave Youth A in temporary placement with
Parent E and Parent F until Tuesday (1/17/2023), when they could
contact RPU (Regional Placement Unit) to conduct a statewide
search for a residential placement. FCW 3 said the agency did
not reach out to the Department of Health and Human services
(DHHS) or DHHS on-call at that time, because it was the
weekend. They also believed Youth A was okay in Parent E’s and
Parent F’s home until the agency could finalize another placement
on that Tuesday, since Monday (1/16/2023) was a holiday.
FCW 3 reported by 1/17/2023 they identified there was a
bed/residential placement via Girl’s Town (a program through their
agency); but the process through RPU was dragging on.
Additionally, Youth A’s birthday was near (2/3) and Youth A and
Friend D’s family wanted to celebrate the birthday event together.
FCW 3 said the re-placement process dragged on and Youth A
remained with Parent E and Parent F. Youth A’s replacement was
pending for 2/13/2023.
6

FCW 3 reported meeting with Parent E on 1/13/2023 and she
visited the family’s home on 1/14/2023. She said Parent E stayed
home with Youth A on 1/17/2023 and brought Youth A to the
agency for most of the day on 1/18/2023. FCW 3 reported daily
phone contacts with Youth A and Friend D’s family. She
completed ICHAT and central registry clearances for the Parent E
and Parent F on 1/14/2023. She said she had not completed the
clearances before because there was no placement exploration
before. She did not observe any marijuana/substance concerns.
She said Youth A’s Guardian Ad Item (GAL) and DHHS case
monitor were aware of the placement situation with Youth A. Both
persons attended a Team Decision Meeting (TDM) on Youth A’s
case, on 1/18/2023. She said, the GAL proposed completing a
motion to have the court do an order that stipulated to Youth A’s
placement at Parent E’s and Parent F’s home. She said the
motion was done, but held off on, because it had been agreed that
Youth A would be placed in a residential setting. Additionally,
Parent E had made it clear they were not willing to plan for Youth
A long term. FCW 3 said Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C
attended the TDM but did not want Youth A to return to them, and
they were not supportive of Youth A’s placement with Parent E
and Parent F. FCW 3 reported Foster Parent B and Foster Parent
C felt Youth A should remain at the agency’s office until the
residential placement occurred. FCW 3 reported Foster Parent B
and Foster Parent C are conscientious and caring people, but they
tended to be very strict. Additionally, they were not allowing her to
do her job and they did not seem to fully understand various
issues of trauma and how such would be impacting on Youth A’s
behaviors.
Reviewed:
Youth A’s physical file and MISACWIS case record which
showed:
• Youth A is a temporary court ward.
• She was placed with Foster Parent B and Foster Parent C
from 1/28/2022 until 1/14/2023.
• She was placed with Parent E on 1/14/2023.
• A Case Service Referral Acceptance -Individual Service
Agreement (DHS-3600) for Guiding Harbor -Girls town for
Youth A, effective 2/6/2023.
• ICHAT clearances for Parent E and Parent F dated
1/4/2023 which showed no criminal notations.
• Undated Central registry and sex offender registry search
documentation for Parent E and Parent F, which FCW
reported completing on 1/14/2023, which showed no
noncompliance.
7

• A 2/15/2023 email from Foster Parent B to Chief
Administrator 1, FCW 3 and two other agency staff
indicating their objection/concern with Youth A’s placement
with Parent E.
• Copy of a Safety plan for Youth A as outlined above, in this
report.
• A TDM dated 1/17/2023 via TEAMS that showed:
➢ Attendance by the TDM facilitator, FCW 3, PM 2,
Guiding Harbor’s licensing worker, and foster care
supervisor, Foster Parent B, Foster Parent C, the
DHHS POS (Purchase of Service) Monitor and the
POS supervisor, Youth A’s father; Parent E, and
Youth A’s GAL.
➢ Youth A AWOLed on 1/13/2023 and again on
1/14/2023. Youth A went to Friend D’s/Parent E’s
(“fictive kin/support”) home and arrangements were
made for her temporary stay at this home over the
weekend.
➢ Youth A is currently at the office, but arrangements
have been made for her to stay the night at the
“fictive kin/support” person’s home if a placement is
not located for her.
➢ The foster parents are not willing to resume
placement and Youth A is refusing to return to the
foster home.
➢ It is anticipated Youth A will remain with the “fictive
kin/support” caregivers until her replacement,
pending completion of a MDHHS- 5770.
• A 1/18/2023 MISACWIS social work contact entry by the
TDM facilitator of all attendees for the 1/17/2023 TDM as
listed earlier in this section. The social work contact also
indicated Youth A’s mother was invited but did not attend
and Youth A refused to attend.
• A DHHS-69 (Action Summary) documenting:
➢ Youth A’s replacement from Foster Parent B’s and
Foster Parent C’s foster home on 1/14/2023 to
Parent E’s and Parent D’s home.
➢ Reason for the replacement.
➢ The reason why Youth A’s replacement to her
parents is not appropriate and feasible at this time.
➢ Youth A’s legal parent/guardian were notified of the
placement change by telephone on 1/14/2023. That
the court was notified via email on the same date.
• A copy of a MDHHS-5770 completed by FCW 3 on
1/24/2023 and approved by PM 2 on 1/31/2023. The
8

agency recommended Youth A’s placement with Parent E
and Parent F based on the following:
➢ The family is willing to have Youth A stay at their
home until another placement is found.
➢ The family has been a past foster and adoptive
family and is somewhat familiar with the effects of
trauma.
➢ The family has been fully informed of Youth A’s
behaviors and needs and they are willing to support
and assist Youth A as needed until another
placement is found.
➢ The family is aware of a safety plan put in place
while Youth A was in placement with Foster Parent
B and Foster Parent C and on 1/14/2023 and
1/18/2023 Parent E agreed to follow that safety plan.
➢ The agency assessed the placement as appropriate
and suitable for an emergency/respite placement for
Youth A.
• Youth A ended up remaining in placement with Parent E
and Parent F for 23 days.
Analysis The agency assessed Parent E’s and Parent F’s home, made
Youth A’s DHHS worker, parents, and GAL aware of the
placement circumstances, and those individuals were in support of
Youth A’s temporary placement with Parent E and F. The agency
made home calls to the home of Parent E and F to assess safety
and found no problems. The agency described the family as a
connection/fictive kin.
Notwithstanding the situation and the agency’s notable efforts, the
agency is in noncompliance of the rule. The agency allowed Youth
A’s to be placed in an unlicensed, unrelated home for 23 days
from 1/14/2023 until 2/6/2023.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the agency current licensing status is recommended.
